item.title: Here's our next batch of Xbox Game Pass games for July
item.content:encoded:
Microsoft has announced the next batch of games being added to Xbox Game Pass for the rest of July.

This batch includes a day one release for Chinese action-RPG Wuchang: Fallen Feathers, as well as a Game Preview for Grounded 2.

The full list is as follows:

  • High On Life (Cloud, Console, and PC) - available with Game Pass Ultimate, PC Game Pass, and Game Pass Standard today
  • RoboCop: Rogue City (Cloud, PC, and Xbox Series X|S) - available with Game Pass Ultimate, PC Game Pass, Game Pass Standard from 17th July
  • My Friendly Neighborhood (Cloud, Console, and PC) - available with Game Pass Ultimate, PC Game Pass from 17th July
  • Back to the Dawn (Cloud, Console, and PC) - available with Game Pass Ultimate, PC Game Pass from 18th July
  • Abiotic Factor (Cloud, PC, and Xbox Series X|S) - available with Game Pass Ultimate, PC Game Pass from 22nd July
  • Wheel World (Cloud, PC, and Xbox Series X|S) - available with Game Pass Ultimate, PC Game Pass from 23rd July
  • Wuchang: Fallen Feathers (Cloud, PC, and Xbox Series X|S) - available with Game Pass Ultimate, PC Game Pass from 24th July
  • Grounded 2 (Game Preview) (Cloud, PC, and Xbox Series X|S) - available with Game Pass Ultimate, PC Game Pass from 29th July
  • Farming Simulator 25 (Cloud, Console, and PC) - available with Game Pass Ultimate, PC Game Pass, Game Pass Standard from 1st August

These additions join the likes of Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 3 + 4, Rise of the Tomb Raider, and Little Nightmares 2 from earlier this month.

Dark fantasy game Wuchang: Fallen Feathers is a twisted wuxia take on the Soulslike formula and one of many action-RPGs to be released from China following in the footsteps of Black Myth: Wukong.

Grounded 2, meanwhile, was announced back at the Xbox Games Showcase in June, but Obsidian told Eurogamer it won't include LAN multiplayer.

The following three games will leave the subscription service on 31st July:

  • Gigantic (Cloud, Console, and PC)
  • Kunitsu-Gami: Path of the Goddess (Cloud, Console, and PC)
  • Turnip Boy Robs a Bank (Cloud, Console, and PC)

For more information on Microsoft's subscription service, check out our guide on all games available on Xbox Game Pass.



https://www.eurogamer.net/heres-our-next-batch-of-xbox-game-pass-games-for-july

item.title: Latest Switch 2 update improves backward compatibility, even though Nintendo's not shouting about it
item.content:encoded:
Plus more stability, of course.

Nintendo has pushed out another Switch 2 system update with typically minimal patch notes. But as delightful as the company's endless quest for "stability improvements" undoubtedly are, users have also starting spotting some undocumented backward compatibility improvements affecting the previously broken likes of Portal 2.

Switch 2's latest update - officially titled Ver. 20.2.0 - arrived overnight, delivering two specifically documented (if not especially thrilling) enhancements for the console. Firstly, it fixed an issue where parental control settings were not being copied from Switch 1 to Switch 2 during system transfer, and then came those "general system stability improvements".

However, word of some secret sauce hidden amid Ver. 20.2.0's mundane documented fixes started circulating soon after. Prominent Switch data miner OatmealDome, for instance, noted it also addressed "some problems" with Switch 1 backwards compatibility. "I can personally confirm that Portal 2 no longer crashes after updating," they added.

Owners had previously found a temporary fix for Portal 2's crashing problem - the issue was seemingly remedied by setting Switch 2 to aeroplane mode before launching the game - but workarounds are needed no more. Alongside user reports of a fix, Nintendo has - as of today, 15th June - now officially updated Portal 2's eShop listing to confirm its compatibility with Switch 2. "Supported," reads the new note. "Game behaviour is consistent with Nintendo Switch."

Other previously wonky games have also been hit with the magic fixing stick following Ver. 20.2.0's release - Crypt of the Necrodancer is another highlighted by users and relabelled as compatible on eShop - but the full extent of Nintendo's tinkering is not yet known. At least we've got those stability improvements to enjoy while the investigations continue.



https://www.eurogamer.net/latest-switch-2-update-improves-backward-compatibility-even-though-nintendos-not-shouting-about-it

item.title: Sony Santa Monica's next game is reportedly "not a new IP" but "it might feel like one"
item.content:encoded:
What's Cory Barlog up to?

Sony Santa Monica, the studio behind the God of War series, is working on a new game, but reportedly it won't be a new IP though "it might feel like one".

There's been plenty of speculation around what the studio may be working on next, in particular game director Cory Barlog. He was responsible for the God of War reboot in 2018, but on its sequel he was producer.

Now, Bloomberg journalist Jason Schreier has addressed the speculation on ResetEra, calling Barlog's game "Sony Santa Monica's next big thing" and that "it was going well" at least a couple of months ago.

In a later response, Schreier added it won't be a new IP and it certainly won't be a sci-fi game.

"I'll put it this way: it’s not a new IP but it might feel like one," Schreier said. "Maybe that's why people are confused. Please don't ask me more questions about this - if I wind up reporting more information at any point in the future it'll be in an article, not on a forum. And that the sci-fi stuff (that people have apparently believed for years now?) is nonsense."

Rumours swirled in August last year that Sony Santa Monica was developing its first new IP in over 20 years.

It's unclear if the studio has multiple projects, or if indeed its next game will be part of an existing franchise. The obvious conclusion is a new game in the God of War series, likely with a new direction.



https://www.eurogamer.net/sony-santa-monicas-next-game-is-reportedly-not-a-new-ip-but-it-might-feel-like-one
